messages.subject: Re: Sadanobu or Teimei
messages.msgSnippet: Kishu no Ju Sadanaga aka Teimei.  I believe the theme may be a foot bridge although traditionally they have five planks if memory serves. see Haynes 07752.0 pp
messages.messageBody:
Kishu no Ju Sadanaga aka Teimei. I believe the theme may be a foot
bridge although traditionally they have five planks if memory serves.

see Haynes 07752.0 pp 1559-1560 -- A group of artists who all signed,
Kishu ju Sadanaga. There were at least four or five generations.
They seem to have come from the early Edo Hoan school. Some read
this name as Teimei. Furukawa catalog pl. 27 #153.
SCE. W - 496-L-2, W - III - 159 - 161.






--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>

this

for

all
> meaning the same thing.
>
> much obliged Gordon.

the onyomi

sufficiently
> > confusing.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sadanobu or Teimei
messages.msgSnippet: indeed it is :-), and as always, I have lots to study. This is most valuable. I will maybe call him Sadamei and start a new trend. :-) There has been
messages.messageBody:
indeed it is :-), and as always, I have lots to study. This is most
valuable. I will maybe call him Sadamei and start a new trend. :-)

There has been suggestions of a Chines motif here but I wonder if this
may be based on a Character or Sanskrit ?. I have seen Ideograms for
Michi ( Do ) that look like and take many interesting forms, but all
meaning the same thing.

much obliged Gordon.

Rich

Richard Turner
Nihontô Message Board
<http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb>
- /for the discussion and sharing of all things Nihontô/





Gordon Robson wrote:
> Hi Rich,

> Not sure what the motif is, but as for the way names are read, typically the
> kunyomi is used or the Japanese pronunciation. However, even sword-smiths
> are given onyomi or Sino-Japanese nicknames. Perhaps the most famous is
> Nagayoshi, who is typically called Chogi. There is also Hiroyoshi, whose
> nickname is Hiroga. Teimei may be a Japanese nickname for Sadanobu. I am
> pretty sure you would read his signature using the kunyomi. On the other
> hand, there are lots of fittings makers whose name is read using the onyomi
> -- Tomei, Somin, all the Goto guys. Even the Omori guys' names are
> pronounced here in Japan using the onyomi. I hope this is sufficiently
> confusing.
>
> Gordon

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Sadanobu or Teimei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, Not sure what the motif is, but as for the way names are read, typically the kunyomi is used or the Japanese pronunciation. However, even sword-smiths
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,

Not sure what the motif is, but as for the way names are read, typically the
kunyomi is used or the Japanese pronunciation. However, even sword-smiths
are given onyomi or Sino-Japanese nicknames. Perhaps the most famous is
Nagayoshi, who is typically called Chogi. There is also Hiroyoshi, whose
nickname is Hiroga. Teimei may be a Japanese nickname for Sadanobu. I am
pretty sure you would read his signature using the kunyomi. On the other
hand, there are lots of fittings makers whose name is read using the onyomi
-- Tomei, Somin, all the Goto guys. Even the Omori guys' names are
pronounced here in Japan using the onyomi. I hope this is sufficiently
confusing.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Wednesday, February 15, 2006 9:21 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Sadanobu or Teimei

Here is an interesting tsuba. Signed Kishu Ju Sadanobu/Teimei. I always
wonder about the reading of this mei. Is one way more correct than the
other ? or are they both right ? ( I also here Sadanaga from time to
time ). I see Nihonto Koza says Sadanobu, I have heard that the Japanese
refer to him as Teimei.

As to the theme, does anyone have an idea what this is ?. Could it be
either walkwaysor maybe an Ideogram of some kind. ?.

it's size is8.2cm x 8cm x 5cm

Cheers

Rich

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/upload/images/Kishu_ju_Teimei_2.jpg



Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Books for Sale
messages.msgSnippet: For SALE:  One set of Toso Kodogu Koza by Wakayama.  This 8 volume encyclopedia covers all areas of fittings.  It is exhaustively illustrated and in excellent
messages.messageBody:
For SALE: One set of Toso Kodogu Koza by Wakayama. This 8 volume
encyclopedia covers all areas of fittings. It is exhaustively
illustrated and in excellent condition. The only other one I could
find for sale on the web was going for $1850. My price- $1125
including domestic shipping. International shipping add $25. Please
email me with any questions. Will consider trade for kokatchushi tsuba
or unusual or large yanone.
Am also seeking an iron kozuka to complete a higo koshirae for a beefy
wak.
Thanks for your time.
Kirk

messages.messageBody:
Sorry for the shameless plug but I though some of you
might be interested. I've listed a few items on Ebay
that some of you might like. Attached are the titles
and links. I've listed all of them with the
tinyurl.com's link so as to save space if they don't
work let me know.

SATSUMA KOSHIRAE: Starting at $50
http://tinyurl.com/l7d4

Touken Midokoro Kandokoro: Starting at $70

Kozuka 100: Starting at $45
http://tinyurl.com/l7dl

Nihon no Bijutu #24: Starting at $45
http://tinyurl.com/l7ds

Sukashi Tsuba: Starting at $70
http://tinyurl.com/l7dw

Yasuknito Shrine Smiths: Starting at $65

Sorry if I just foiled any of you snipers hopes for an
easy kill but its more fun if your target is moving
right? Thanks for everyone's time.

Bob R

P.S. I'll be adding items throughout the coming weeks
so here's the URL to my Ebay page if you want to see
whats new. http://tinyurl.com/l7ej
